turns.content: Hello! My name is Yuki Tanaka. I moved to Canada six months ago and I still have trouble with some things. Can you help me?
Hi Yuki! Of course, I'd be glad to help. What kinds of things are you finding difficult since your move?
I am from Osaka, Japan, and now I live in Toronto. The biggest challenge is my English. I understand most things when I read, but speaking and listening in fast conversations is hard for me.
That's completely normal. Reading and listening are different skills, and spoken English in Toronto can be fast with a lot of slang. Are you taking any English classes right now?
Yes, I take English classes three evenings a week at a language school downtown. During the day I work at a Japanese restaurant called Sakura Kitchen. I'm a server there.
Working at a restaurant is actually great for practicing English since you interact with customers all day. How is the job at Sakura Kitchen going?

It's good. The owner is from Kyoto so we speak Japanese together sometimes, which feels like home. But most of the customers speak English, so I get a lot of practice. Some regulars are very patient with me.
Having a boss who speaks your language must be comforting, and the English practice with customers is invaluable. Do you have any bigger goals you're working toward in Canada?

Yes! My dream is to get into the University of Toronto for computer science. I studied programming a little in Osaka and I really love it. But I need to improve my English score first for the admission requirements.
That's an excellent goal. U of T has a strong computer science program. Do you know which English proficiency test you need to take â€” IELTS or TOEFL?
I'm preparing for the IELTS. My language school teacher said I need at least a 6.5 overall score. Right now I think I'm around a 5.5, so I still have work to do.
Going from 5.5 to 6.5 is very achievable, especially since you're immersed in an English-speaking environment. How much time are you giving yourself to prepare?

I want to take the test in about eight months. That would let me apply for the fall intake next year. I also do some coding practice on the side using online tutorials to keep my programming skills fresh.
Eight months is a good timeline. Combining English study with coding practice is smart because a lot of programming resources are in English anyway. What programming languages have you worked with?
Mostly Python and a little bit of JavaScript. I built a small website for Sakura Kitchen as a project to practice both my coding and my English writing. The owner was really happy with it.

That's a fantastic way to combine your skills. Building a real project for someone is much better practice than just doing exercises. You could even add it to a portfolio when you apply to U of T. Keep up the great work, Yuki.

recallQuestions.question: What is the user's name and where is she originally from?
Where does Yuki currently live and work?
recallQuestions.expectedAnswer: She lives in Toronto, Canada, and works at a Japanese restaurant called Sakura Kitchen

recallQuestions.question: What is Yuki's main academic goal?
recallQuestions.expectedAnswer: To get into the University of Toronto for computer science

recallQuestions.question: What English proficiency test is Yuki preparing for, and what score does she need?
recallQuestions.expectedAnswer: IELTS, she needs at least a 6.5 overall score

recallQuestions.question: What programming languages does Yuki know, and what project did she build?
recallQuestions.expectedAnswer: Python and JavaScript. She built a small website for Sakura Kitchen.
